title: Will the FAO Food Price Index for April 2022 reach or exceed 150.0?
preds: Time update and it looks like 157. To date

Given that the index averaged 159.3 points in March, it seems likely that the April price will exceed 150. Conflict in Ukraine pushed the price of wheat higher in March, and it seems likely that that will continue to put upward pressure on prices into April. Source: https://www.fao.org/newsroom/detail/fao-food-price-index-posts-significant-leap-in-march/en
It has come at 159 on April 7th release. Of the components - oil is likely to be high as Indonesia banned exports, Cerreal will continue to remain high due to Ukraine war

March reference is already above this level primarily due to concerns over wheat exports from Russia and Ukraine, while higher fertilizer prices could negatively impact the level of technology used on most crops and should affect the world's SnD. Protective measures from some governments should also help sustain a higher reference.
Vast majority of inputs point to higher pricing to maintain levels already above the target.
With the figure being 159 for March and the pressure on the food supply chain due to the conflict in Ukraine, looks very likely to breach the 150 level.

Russia-Ukraine war is putting pressure on the wheat market, which in turn is driving demand for other agricultural commodities.  Fertilizers (from Russia and Belarus) not making it to farms is also affecting cereal and grain agricultural commodities.
With pressure on grains etc, I think it will be above 150
Wheat prices soaring, trending higher, seems like all food input prices trading higher through April as well. Highly likely to see the index price in >150.
Very high probability that this will cross the target level.
Trend is certainly in this direction.
March numbers had a jump of nearly 18 points from Feb (141 to 159) - the current geopolitical climate remains unchanged - i'm expecting April to top 160
Already reached target in March, unlikely to drop below in April
This sucked.. this one got away from me.
Well, at 159 now so I guess so.

March figure was 159.3, so well over the 150 threshold. For the question to resolve no the index would have to drop by 9.3 points in April, which seems so out of the realms of possibility at the moment given the emerging food situation.

Kudos to @slapthepancake, who calculated a March value of 157.4 - 158.8 (the fact that such predictions seemed ridiculous at the time should be a lesson for all of us):
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1424151
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1424240
Based on March release being well above target

The March index had the largest jump on record, up 12% to 159.3 [1]. So,  only chance for question to fail now is for index to drop significantly. Macro events suggest this is highly unlikely.  [1] https://www.fao.org/worldfoodsituation/foodpricesindex/en/

Based on current grain prices, I wrote on March 19 that, "I think the March FFPI value will likely be somewhere in the range of 147.0-150.5." Based on that analysis, I forecast that it was 100% certain that April would see the index >= 150.0. However, my estimate for March was clearly too conservative. From today's press release: "The FAO Food Price Index* (FFPI) averaged 159.3 points in March 2022, up 17.9 points (12.6 percent) from February." That April's index value will be >= 150.0 is all but assured, as cash and futures prices remain extremely high in grain, oilseed, palm oil, meat, dairy, sugar and fertilizer markets.

March numbers in: he FAO Food Price Index* (FFPI) averaged 159.3 points in March 2022, up 17.9 points (12.6 percent) from February, making a giant leap to a new highest level since its inception in 1990. The latest increase reflects new all-time highs for vegetable oils, cereals and meat sub-indices, while those of sugar and dairy products also rose significantly.
March index now reported at 159.3, up 17.9 points (!!!) m-o-m. Hard to see the world getting back to normal “baseline” conditions in 23 days. All in.

Increasing liklihood given the print this AM https://www.fao.org/worldfoodsituation/foodpricesindex. I need to spend some time this weekend figuring out the methodology of the index to see if there's a chance it comes off next month sequentially. But seems like the input pressures are persisting given geopolitical crunches etc. Seems likely it stays elevated above 150.

@slapthepancake's calculations were clearly correct and mine were off. Based on my new calcs I have it at 154 for April, so bumping materially.
@Sebbe FYI

"The FFPI averaged 140.7 points in February 2022, up 5.3 points from January and as much as 24.1 points above its level a year ago -- a new all-time high, exceeding the previous top of February 2011 by 3.1 points. 
The February rise was led by large increases in vegetable oil and dairy price sub-indices. Cereals and meat prices were also up, while the sugar price sub-index fell for the third consecutive month" 
Have we seen the worst of it yet, or is April too soon to see the worst of it this year? If the index continues to rise at current levels for March (numbers release on April 8), then April, then it can easily reach 150.0 but given that the index it's already at its all time high by 3.1 pts, one would imagine strong measures are being taken to control prices. Supply issues are being addressed, weather has affected crops in major producers like Canada, Brazil, and the pandemic is relatively under control, but war in Ukraine is not showing signs or easing. 
Brent oil went below $100 for the first time today since Russia invaded Ukraine in late February, as uncertainty that the euro zone will be able to effectively sanction Russian energy exports eases and huge release of oil from emergency reserves are announced. Lockdowns in China, where over 23 cities and 100 million people remain on lockdown because of Covid19 outbreak are expected to slow oil demand. Could be that impact of rise in oil prices has already been priced in for March and would easy in April. Let's see what March numbers show.
https://www.fao.org/worldfoodsituation/foodpricesindex/en/
risen more than seen in a very long time, but new #s out this week, so revision imminent.
it'll increase, but i don't think it'll break 150.0
Current pressure on foodstuffs as a result Ukraine conflict means highly probable.
Food oil prices continuing to rise so that will impact the score to increase as well
140.7 in February, up 5.3 points from January. The impact of the Russia-Ukraine war is yet to be reflected in the index.

In working on this question (https://app.datacamp.com/workspace/w/9cef92f2-009c-4572-b17e-b5db07bea220) - and I'm not finished yet, so I'll come back and update later - I think the FAO Food Price Index will go up by 10 points over the next 12 months. I think a jump of 10 points in one month is unlikely. Additionally, I think there is a cyclical nature to food prices, so I think the value will be closer to the April 2021 value.
Cereals will be impacted materially by Russia/Ukraine ... pressure on oils will continue,  but I think the index will be between 145 and 150, not over 150.
The world has moved quickly to adjust for loss in oil supply, reserves of food stuffs and other commodities are also being sourced and used to support the current position we are in.
140 to 150 is a 7% MoM change. Base rate of such change is very low - less than 2% in 30 years data. Has war disruptions been so severe?  Not yet at least

Next update on 7 April,  Cereals may be impacted by Ukraine but production was anticipated already to be reduced,  now it might go completely which would potential alter supply ratios.  Will hedge upward and check again after next update.

This is a very long-winded way of saying the crowd is probably right and there's probably little margin to outperform on this question :(. Prices look poised to jump above 150 in March based on their prices thus far, and while there's a chance they'll decrease in April back below the threshold, it doesn't seem likely to me unless the March jump is lower than expected. ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ I approached this one by first getting a forecast for the FFPI by taking each of the 5 individual components and doing a linear regression on each according to their most recent trend. The result of that in my method was 141.8 in March and 143.8 in April, which isn't promising. The index historically doesn't tend to have dramatic swings between months either. But they obvious issue is that there have been dramatic changes in commodity prices that need to be accounted for. I ended up using two approaches to estimate the effect of those shocks as I mulled the question over. Firstly I attempted to reconstruct the FFPI using historic futures market data for some of the items that make up each component. For each component (wheat, palm oil, milk, etc.) I got prices for February and March multiplying volume x price for traded futures, seeing what the month-over-month percent change was, and applying those to the FFPI index categories. A breakdown of the proxies I used for each index component is below. The correlation between the dairy/cereals/oils components and the actual index is .83 for Apr'21-Feb'22 (using month-end price), which is decent enough for what I need. The predictions from that model are for the FFPI to jump to 157.4 in March, which is a pretty ridiculous jump. I added a second approach for a few reasons. Firstly, I was finally able to (I think) find out how the FFPI sources its data, and do a more informed prediction from there. Secondly, futures and FFPI indices track decently in normal times, but I'm not sure if that link holds up during shocks. For example, wheat futures recently jumped ~40%, while the IGC wheat index that the FPI uses jumped only ~23%. Thirdly, a jump of 17 points is a pretty outlandish result considering the history of the index, so I'd want to double-check that. Unfortunately for this approach though, the meat index doesn't have a listed source (and is hard to source in the other approach as well), and the oils data is behind a paywall, so I'm ignoring those for now. In the second approach, using March data so far, dairy should jump 5%, cereals 19%, and sugar 6%. The combination of those effects should be a 9.2 point bump in the index, up to 149.9. That's before factoring in the sizeable increases in vegetable oil prices, which were the second largest contributor to growth in the futures-based model, as well as any potential meat increases. So in both models we'll be solidly above 150 in March.  The question that that begs though is whether the price hikes will be durable, since we're forecasting April instead of March. I'm inclined to say yes for a number of reasons. Part of the overall increase is inflation, since this question is citing nominal instead of real numbers based on USD, and inflation has been accelerating for months and (at least for the EU) isn't expected to peak for another month or so. Prices across the board are also being driven higher partly by oil prices affecting freight costs and operational costs for farming equipment. That doesn't seem likely to go down soon (https://www.cbsnews.com/news/gas-prices-high-expensive-come-down-cbs-news-explains/), both because I'm not expecting a resolution in Ukraine and because it doesn't seem like OPEC is poised to substantially increase output (https://www.ft.com/content/648e0f28-3dd4-4132-af53-fb9490f6ac11). The OPEC meeting on the 31st will be important to watch. Vegetable oil prices will likely remain high since the price spike seems to be due to bad weather in South America and Indonesia/Malaysia (https://www.marketplace.org/2022/02/17/oil-prices-surge-vegetable-oil-that-is/), though they may decrease from their dramatically elevated March levels. Wheat prices will likely remain elevated due to the Ukraine conflict, and the price hikes there have been pretty stable throughout March, so I'm inclined to believe they'll stay high. Dairy prices seem to be driven by higher energy, as well as by labor costs since most exports come from the EU and Oceania.  The chance that prices will go down a bit after a dramatic jump is a very real possibility though, and one to take seriously, which keeps me from putting my confidence any higher. Prices spiking as people panic and then receding back down as demand shifts, oil production increases, supply chains adapt, etc. is not an unreasonable scenario. If the index jumps to only 150 or so in March then I'll seriously need to reevaluate this. But at least given what we know now, the index should jump substantially, with the increase most likely a lasting one.  Approach #1 breakdown:
Meat (33%): use historic average, chickens are 38% of the index and don't have a futures market to reference. Prices have been stable for the past few months and there's minimal change since February in cattle and pork prices which make up 62% of the index, so assuming its flat is probably fine. Dairy (14%): Class III milk futures Cereals (29%): 43% wheat prices, 46% corn futures (as a proxy for rough grain, of which it's ~80%), 11% rough rice futures Oils (17%): 44% palm oil futures, 35% soybean oil futures, 20% rapeseed oil futures Sugar(7%): Sugar #11 futures FFPI category weights: https://iussp.org/sites/default/files/Shirley_Mustafa_FFPI.pdf
Cereals index component weights: https://www.fao.org/worldfoodsituation/csdb/en/ (download data, sum 2014-2016 trade volumes as % of whole)
Vegetable oil market component weights: https://www.statista.com/statistics/263937/vegetable-oils-global-consumption/ Milk futures: https://www.investing.com/commodities/class-iii-milk-futures-historical-data
Wheat price history: https://www.macrotrends.net/2534/wheat-prices-historical-chart-data
Corn futures: https://www.investing.com/commodities/us-corn-historical-data
Rice futures: https://www.investing.com/commodities/rough-rice-historical-data
Palm oil futures: https://www.investing.com/commodities/palm-oil-historical-data
Soybean oil futures: https://www.investing.com/commodities/us-soybean-oil-historical-data
Rapeseed oil futures: https://www.investing.com/commodities/rapeseed-historical-data
Sugar futures: https://www.investing.com/commodities/us-sugar-no11-historical-data Approach #2 breakdown: Meat (33%): not addressed, sources not listed Dairy (14%): 62% simple average of EU changes in butter, SMP, WMP, cheddar, 38% simple average of Oceania SMP, WMP Cereals (29%): 43% IGC wheat, 38% IGC maize, 8% IGC barley, 11% IGC rice (actual index uses different rice source) Oils (17%): not used, data behind paywall Sugar (7%): 100% ISA daily price Data sources and methods: https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/cb4479en.pdf , cereals on page 176, oils, sugar, and dairy in footnotes to appendix tables 24, 25, and 26
IGC grain indices: https://www.igc.int/en/markets/marketinfo-goi.aspx
ISA sugar prices (not ICE futures, but close enough for me): https://www.isosugar.org/prices.php?pricerange=2022-02-01
Vegetable oil prices (paywall): https://www.oilworld.biz/t/publications/weekly

The outside view would probably suggest no, based on the base rate of the measure never having exceeded 150 before. The dataset shows the largest 2 month gain since 1990 was 14.2, in the summer of 2020. The average gain since 1990 is 0.5 and the median is 0.2. I think this is a case where the outside view isn't that useful. The index would have to gain 9.3 points over the next two months to exceed, and the invasion of Ukraine kicked off in February, so the latest February number won't include the effects of that, and the impacts to wheat and other crops are expected to be high. So I think it's likely to exceed.

Trending substantially upwards to record levels which were recorded pre the impact of the war in Ukraine, this global shortage seems to suggest it would continue rising steeply since the last closing prices.
Just repeating my forecast to post this: https://www.nytimes.com/2022/03/20/world/americas/ukraine-war-global-food-crisis.html

The monthly changes are positively autocorrelated and with big rises recently more big rises are likely.  I got a 25% chance of a 2 month change of 6.6% contingent on the preceding month being up more than 3.5%.  Without the contingency the chance of a move that large was 6.5%.  So generally moves this big are rare but in the current environment not that uncommon.   Commodity prices are up since the end of February and it is not hard to find news stories about how important the Ukraine / Russia conflict is to the wheat market so I have added another 13%.  The general pandemic supply shortages causing inflation over the last year seem to persist as well so it would be hard to imagine my rough statistics should be adjusted lower.

Wheat spot prices have climbed 25% since the war began (spiked even higher than that, but has since come down), and I assume cereals are some substantial % of the FAO food price index (but not sure what % goes to wheat -- the other cereals haven't climbed as much, other than corn at +15%).

I was at 95%, but realistically, there's <0.5% chance the FFPI will be below 150.0 in April. The index went up 5.3 points to 140.7 in Feb, based on data largely before the invasion of Ukraine. Since Feb 28, wheat prices spiked up ~40% higher than closing prices on Feb 28 and have since fallen to ~20% higher than Feb 28 close prices. Feb 28 close prices were already substantially higher than the previous year's prices and higher than everything since early 2011. The last time wheat prices were this high was in the first half of 2008, when there were riots all over the world because so many people couldn't afford food. Oilseed prices have also gone up: canola is at an all-time high, and soybeans are near all-time highs and above last month's average. Sunflower jumped on news of the invasion and may be coming down to a higher level. Palm oil jumped on news of the invasion but appears to have come down, possibly to resume its upward trend. On top of that, fertilizer prices are still at all-time highs, and climbing. Corn prices jumped after the invasion, are about 15% higher than Feb 28 closing prices and are not that far from all-time highs. Rice prices continue to climb. And the pandemic dislocations that had brought the index into the 130's are all still relevant. If the index climbed 5.3 points in Feb, I don't see how it won't climb substantially more in March. Increases could slow in April, but I don't see how all of this could be reversed enough to bring the index under 150 in April. The FFPI is calculated in a slightly complicated way, with each commodity weighted according to its share of exports in 2014-2016. For the sake of argument, let's suppose that each sub-index of the FFPI is weighted about 1/5. For Feb 22, this overestimates the index by 1.5. Let's suppose that the cereals index increases by 10% in March, which is probably an underestimate, and that the vegetable oils index increases by, say, 8%. If all else stayed constant, and subtracting off the excess 1.5, this would bring the index to a crude estimate of 146.8 for March. But milk and cheese are continuing their substantial climb, and meat and sugar also look likely to be higher in March. So I think the March FFPI value will likely be somewhere in the range of 147.0-150.5, and probably towards the higher end of that range. If April only climbs a little (or possibly stays flat, depending on the March value), the index will be over 150.0. It's useful to look at past movements and values of the FFPI. Some here note that reaching 150.0 in April would be highly anomalous. This is true. The FFPI hasn't reached 150 since it started being calculated in 1961 (normalized to 2014-2016 prices). The reason why I'm certain the FFPI will reach or exceed 150.0 is because current circumstances are extremely anomalous. On top of already high prices because of a multitude of effects of the pandemic, Russia invaded Ukraine, and this has had a gigantic and immediate effect on grain and oilseed/veg oil prices. Russia and Ukraine together account for 25% of global wheat exports, and Ukraine is a heavyweight in oilseed exports. Hence, I don't think it's useful to compare what's about to happen to recent times or recent specific events. I don't think a comparison to 2007-2008 is very useful, either, because that situation evolved over time and was not the result of a sudden shock, whereas we're experiencing a sudden shock now from the invasion of Ukraine. So, I don't think past movements of the index really apply here. We are in an unprecedented situation that can be expected to have profound consequences around the world if it is not resolved quickly, and I don't think it will be resolved quickly. https://tradingeconomics.com/commodities

Nudge up to align with others as well as for anomalous times. The reason I'm so low relative to the crowd median right now is due to the low volatility or variation of the trend, which tells me it is more predictable. However, I may be dis-weighting the relevancy of how things have changed significantly.

@kevins point is fair on whether it will hold through April. March data will be incredibly telling. MY suspicion is that  it will given the growing food supply impacts from Russia/Ukraine conflict and the ongoing supply chains issues globally. With fertilizer markets disrupted as well, the food input costs are going to continue to rise. Some sources here highlight the issues: https://www.politico.eu/article/war-in-ukraine-global-food-system-wheat-trade-export/; https://www.cbc.ca/news/business/wheat-prices-ukraine-1.6377239; https://www.world-grain.com/articles/16600-faos-food-price-index-reaches-all-time-high-in-february

I think that although the war in Ukraine won't be affecting supply chains just yet, it's being priced in already. I think we might see the index for March tip above 150.0 based on the data at that link. The difficulty I think is determining whether it will stay at the level it's currently at.
Currently at 140, its been consistently rising with inflation. Oils, Cereals & Dairy all rising.  Likely to continue.  Meat and sugar flat.

The FAO Food Price Index is at 140.7 points as of the last time it was released in February 2022 (https://www.fao.org/worldfoodsituation/foodpricesindex/en/). From what I can tell, tracking monthly prices back through February 2021, a 10 point increase over two months has never happened.
I have done a bit more work on this and I think my initial thoughts were off. Dropping substantially.

Asked, any commodities trader will show high concern for this event. In poorer countries, where price moves are harder to be hampered by govs etc., strong increases can be observed already. Should the Ukraine-Russia war last some more weeks, we could reach a territory where the harvest, essential to global food markets might not be produced in time. Ukraine's president, Zelenky recently urged farmes to seed even in the face of war to stabilize the GDP. This shows the significance of the conflict. Instabilities and global inflation threaten these price levels, why I think they are likely to appear.

3/17: All signs are pointing to increasing food prices: several severe droughts, increase in fuel/fertilizer/wheat prices due to Russia war on Ukraine, poor crop expectations in China (wheat).  So the question is whether we've seen all of this priced in already or not.  I don't think we have since the war that is triggering several of these only started in late February.  So it is probable that we see a similar, if not higher increase rate in March and a more mild increase by the time April data is available.

In the not too distant future given the roll of Ukraine in food production I expect this increase. Just a matter of whether this impact can manifest by April or a lag in the indicator prevents it by April.

9.3 index points to go with 2 releases, so need 4.6 increase in both months.
Feb 22 increase was 5.2 so this is possible.   Given the impact of little crop from Ukraine and people will be buying that far into the future, sanctions on Russia and the impact of fertiliser costs, because Russia and Ukraine also supply a lot of potash, plus the cost of fuel, currently increasing, also filters into food prices.  I think food prices will keep going up and probably quite fast in the next couple of months before stabilising.

The Index hit 140.1 in February, so hitting target would require an increase of 7% over two months.  Looking at the historic data on the FAO site going back to 1990, there have been 17 two-month periods with that minimum increase (17 out of 384 period, or 4.4%), with 39 periods jumping 5% or more (10% of total).  So, jump is rare, but not unheard of.   Looking at current situation, commodity prices have jumped following Putin's invasion of Ukraine, with particularly relevant impact on wheat  prices (Russia and Ukraine are responsible for 25% of global production of wheat) [1] . Wheat prices have jumped over 30% since Putin invaded [2]. A resolution to the Ukraine situation and a return to previous trade levels seems unlikely to happen in the next few weeks.  Oil price jump is likely to be reflected in commodity prices, too. Market volatility is likely to have affected other relevant commodities, although others may be less reliant on these two countries.   So, base case seems to be about 5-10% chance of a jump, but current conditions lead me to increase probability slightly.  [1] https://oec.world/en/profile/hs92/wheat
[2] https://markets.businessinsider.com/commodities/wheat-price

When oil prices increase so does food with the high at 140.7 and oil decreasing in price and the world has adjusted to the war in Ukraine I don’t believe it will reach 150.0 in the time frame of the question. Since posting no new data …

Historical price index in periods of geopolitical instability and economic uncertainty drive my forecast in this short timeframe that has a high presence of both of these elements heavily towards sustained high food prices that reach or exceed 150.  Further driving this likelihood higher is the historical data in question largely was not directly related to massive sanctions on one of the top energy and foodstuff suppliers in the world.  Further, in this previous instance the areas of kinetic war did not include major energy/foodstuff countries directly.
Already  140.7 in February, up 5.3 points in January. With the Ukraine war impacting wheat prices, it is very likely to increase another 10 points in two months.

Hard to tell how food prices will react to the current geopolitical situation. 2021 was already a high year and the difference between Feb 2021 and Fewb 2022 is considerable. I currently bet on increasing prices, but this estimate could be updated considerably once the index for March is published.

The index was up 5.3 points before Russia invaded Ukraine. Grain and oilseed prices have gone up steeply since then because of Russia's invasion of Ukraine, as both countries are heavy exporters of grains (e.g., 25% of world wheat exports) and also oilseeds (#6 and #7 for oilseed exports in the world). The index is already at 140.7 for Feb. It will be up sharply in March, possibly even over 150.0 then. April could be worse, and it probably won't be better.

I'm guesstimating 3%-4% increase for March and for April (February saw a 3.9% increase), putting the April number between 149 and 152 "Food Price Monitoring and Analysis (FPMA) Bulletin #2", 10 March 2022, https://www.fao.org/3/cb8976en/cb8976en.pdf
Average of two base rates I generated, but I recall that my survey phase forecast was around 50/50 or 60/40 in favor of YES.
This would imply a very large increase, but Ukraine / supply chain, etc. make it somewhat possible.

This would be quite the gap up, but looking at the International Grains Council (IGC) figures on wheat since the last readout, the increases are staggering: https://www.igc.int/en/markets/marketinfo-prices.aspx I'm not sure how much I am competent to extrapolate without deeper knowledge of the index construction, but it seems like the wheat portion of the index is set to spike again and that might put 150 for April within striking distance. I guess we'll find out more on April 3.

Not only are there issues with Ukraine/Russia and Soy harvests in SA (h/t @steven_meyer), China is also having issues (https://asia.nikkei.com/Business/Agriculture/China-warns-of-worst-in-history-winter-wheat-crop).

This would be an unprecedently fast increase given past monthly increases. UN says global food prices could go up by 20% this year. The problem I have is timescale, namely that many crops aren't due in the next month. I think short term the main shock will be from energy prices boosting cost of transportation of food, but oil price is already going back down. For the index to go from 140 to 150 would be a roughly 8% increase. If the UN thinks prices go up to 20% by 2023, 8% only in the next two months is very fast, especially with wheat harvest not due until June. It also seems like the initial price shock resulting from the war may already have been partly incorporated into February's index price, making this even less likely than it seems.
Seems very unlikely to rise that much by April based on historical trends and rates of increase. Wheat prices are already stabilising-

As of writing this forecast the latest FAO Food Price Index was 140.7 as per the February reading. This is a new all time high for the index, with prices being on a drastic rise since 2020. This most recent rise can mainly be attributed to supply shocks caused by the ongoing conflict in Ukraine(Cereal -- ie Wheat & Vegetable Oil -- ie sunflower oil), issue with the South American Soy harvest (Vegetable Oil -- ie Soy Oil), and decreased Palm Oil Exports from Indonesia (Vegetable Oil). Putting immense upward pressure on the price of Cereal and Vegetable Oil components of the Index. It appears to me that most of these situations are not likely to be resolved quickly (ie in time for this year's harvest). As such, I would expect upward pressure to continue; especially as continued elevated Cereal prices are likely to put upward pressures on the Diary and Meat components of the index as the cost of feed is increased. This combined with generally high inflation and surging commodity costs (Oil especially increasing farmers input costs) would leave me with a base case where the FAO Food index continues to rise notably from it's already elevated levels. I am leaving 5% margin of error to account for cases where a) the Russian-Ukrainian invasion is resolved quickly b) Commodity prices for some reason reverse their spike bringing down input costs. c) all of my concerns stated in the above are already fully priced into the current price
